div.p: Greetings. Not long ago, I wrote to your kindness, dearest Bullinger, and along with my letter, I enclosed many others received from England and Hooper. I sent them to Valentin Nußbaum in Basel, so that they might be delivered to you more safely through him; for here, a courier is rarely found except at the fairs. In my letters, I wrote that our Hooper was elected to the office of bishop by the king and the senate of England, which is confirmed to be certain. I pray to God that he may preside well over this office. Our Strasbourg, as the rumor goes, is in turmoil; for three churches are granted to the papists, in which they freely practice their errors.

The people are divided among themselves: some praise papism; however, the greater part opposes it. Some old men and matrons, contrary to everyone's opinion, adhere to the truth; religion remains free, as do the preachers. Many doubt what monstrosity the Council of Augsburg may foster. In England, all is calm; religion is making progress.

There is no rumor here that the Emperor will attack you, nor do I predict it arising from anywhere else among you than from the opinion of soldiers, who each measure the Emperor by their own judgment. Rather, I am convinced that he will wage war on the cities.

If I hear anything unfavorable about your Switzerland, I will not remain silent. In the meantime, we must pray to God to grant peace. Farewell, most esteemed friend. My family sends their regards to you and yours.

Through Falkner, I sent a large bundle of letters addressed to Mr. Pellican, whom I ask you to greet in my name. Your books and letters were brought to England long ago. I also received letters from Mr. Theodor, which I immediately sent by courier, whom I ask you to commend me to and to tell these things. Farewell again. The bustle of the fairs does not allow me to linger any longer. Strasbourg, July 10.

Mr. Gwalter wrote to me about the painted panels prepared for Mr. Hales. I have never heard anything from him about them; however, I will write and, if he orders, I will pay the money. Seventeen days ago, I sent a package from Hooper to you and a basket from Hales to Mr. Gwalter; I hope you have received them.
To the honorable and wise Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my kind lord and friend.
